sentences.text: Throughout his presidency, Bukele's government was described as authoritarianism|authoritarian and autocracy|autocratic, resulting in what many journalists described as democratic backsliding. His COVID-19 lockdowns were criticized when the National Civil Police (El Salvador)|National Civil Police arrested more than 4,200 people. In February 2020, he was criticized for 2020 Salvadoran political crisis|sending 40 soldiers into the Legislative Assembly to pressure lawmakers to approve a US$109 million loan to fund the Territorial Control Plan, a security program initiated by Bukele, in what critics described as an attempted coup d'√©tat. In September 2020, El Faro (digital newspaper)|''El Faro'' accused Bukele of negotiating with Crime in El Salvador#Gangs|criminal gangs in the country, notably MS-13|Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang, to lower crime rates. Bukele and his government denied those accusations. The United States government labeled various Bukele government officials as Corruption in El Salvador|corrupt. In the 2021 Salvadoran legislative election|2021 legislative election, Nuevas Ideas, the political party Bukele established, won Supermajority|supermajorities in the Legislative Assembly of El Salvador|Legislative Assembly, Municipalities of El Salvador|municipalities, and the Central American Parliament (PARLACEN). The List of members of the XIII Legislative Assembly of El Salvador|13th session of the Legislative Assembly assumed office on 1 May 2021, and Ernesto Castro was elected as the List of presidents of the Legislative Assembly of El Salvador|president of the Legislative Assembly. Following Castro's election, the 64 legislators representing {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}, GANA, the Christian Democratic Party (El Salvador)|Christian Democratic Party (PDC), and the National Coalition Party (El Salvador)|National Coalition Party (PCN) 2021 Salvadoran political crisis|voted to remove Attorney General Ra√∫l Melara and five Supreme Court justices from the constitutional court. Bukele later appointed a new attorney general and new justices in what has since been described as a self-coup.

sentences.text: Following a spike in murders in March 2022, Bukele's government began a Salvadoran gang crackdown|gang crackdown, referred to as a state of exception and a war against gangs, which resulted in the reported arrests of over 75,163 alleged gang members by 11 January 2024 and 144 to 152 deaths in custody by 10 May 2023. The crackdown, which had since been extended several times, has been accused of engaging in Arbitrary arrest and detention|arbitrary arrests, torture, and Human rights in El Salvador|human rights abuses by organizations such as Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch. On 3 January 2023, Minister of Defense Ren√© Merino Monroy announced that 496 homicides were recorded in 2022, a decrease from 1,147 homicides in 2021; Merino attributed the decrease to the gang crackdown. Politicians from ARENA, the FMLN, and Nuestro Tiempo (El Salvador)|Nuestro Tiempo described the crackdown as a political and electoral strategy to support the government and intimidate the opposition.

sentences.text: Despite controversies and negative press coverage, Opinion polling on the Nayib Bukele presidency|Bukele remains extremely popular with approval ratings consistently hovering between 80 and 90{{Nbsp}}percent. He is considered to be one of the most popular presidents in El Salvador's history, as well as one of the most popular incumbent Latin American heads of state.

sentences.text:
{{see also|Continuismo}}
On 3 September 2021, the Supreme Court of Justice of El Salvador|Supreme Court of Justice ruled that the president of El Salvador is eligible to run for re-election in consecutive terms, discarding a 2014 ruling that required presidents to wait ten years before running for re-election. The 2021 court ruling made Bukele eligible to run for president in 2024. Despite protests from ARENA and the FMLN, the Supreme Electoral Court (El Salvador)|Supreme Electoral Court (TSE) accepted the Supreme Court's ruling. Charg√© d'affaires|Charg√© d'Affaires Jean Elizabeth Manes compared the path the Salvadoran government was taking to that of Venezuela under Hugo Ch√°vez. On 1 March 2023, four of the five members of the Supreme Court's Constitutional Chamber confirmed that presidential re-election is allowed.

sentences.text: During a speech on the country's Act of Independence of Central America|201st anniversary of independence from Spanish Empire|Spain on 15 September 2022, Bukele officially announced his re-election campaign despite having previously voiced his opposition to immediate re-election both before and during his presidency. Bukele justified his re-election bid by arguing that most Developed country|developed countries allow re-election; he read a list of 39 countries the International Monetary Fund (IMF) considers "developed," and stated that all the countries on the list, except for South Korea, allowed re-election. He also claimed that restrictions on re-election only exists in Third World|third-world countries. According to Bukele, a developed country criticizing his announcement would be hypocritical. and on 9 July, {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} officially elected Bukele as its presidential candidate.

sentences.text: Bukele is the first person since Brigadier General Maximiliano Hern√°ndez Mart√≠nez (in office 1931‚Äì1934 and 1935‚Äì1944) to be re-elected and serve multiple terms as president. Additionally, he was the first president since Antonio Saca (served 2004‚Äì2009) to seek re-election.{{efn|Saca's re-election bid was for the 2014 Salvadoran presidential election|2014 presidential election, one election cycle after his initial election in 2004 Salvadoran presidential election|2004.}} Bukele has been compared to Juan Orlando Hern√°ndez in Honduras and Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua, who used the Supreme Court and constitutional reforms, respectively, in their own countries to allow themselves to run for re-election. According to a poll conducted by the Francisco Gavidia University (UFG) in October 2022, 76 percent of respondents believed that if Bukele were re-elected in 2024, he would run for a third term in the 2029 Salvadoran presidential election|2029 presidential election.

sentences.text: Bukele's announcement that he was running for re-election was criticized by constitutional lawyers, who said his re-election would be Constitutionality|unconstitutional and violate at least four articles of El Salvador's constitution. Following Bukele's registration as a presidential pre-candidate, Eduardo Escobar, the executive director of the Citizen Action non-governmental organization, stated that "everything is unconstitutional and they are only trying to give a face of legitimacy to everything with these gimmicks" ("{{lang|es|todo es inconstitucional y solo est√°n tratando de darle una cara de legitimidad a todo con estos artilugios}}"). Manuel Flores (Salvadoran politician)|Manuel Flores, then the FMLN's presidential pre-candidate, stated that "the law is the law [and] the law says that there is no re-election" ("{{lang|es|la ley es la ley [y] la ley dice que no hay reelecci√≥n}}"), adding that the Constitution of El Salvador|constitution is "clear" ("{{lang|es|clara}}") in prohibiting re-election. Citizen Resistance politician Rub√©n Zamora stated that the Legislative Assembly had to suspend Bukele's rights as a Salvadoran citizen in accordance with the constitution for registering as a pre-candidate for presidential re-election. Both Zamora and Claudia Ortiz (El Salvador)|Claudia Ortiz, a deputy from Vamos, argued that articles 75, 88, 131, 152, 154, and 248 of the country's constitution prohibit immediate re-election.

sentences.text: On 1 May 2023, 36 left-wing organizations‚Äîincluding the FMLN and {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}‚Äî2023 Salvadoran protests|held a protest march on International Workers' Day against Bukele's re-election campaign and the gang crackdown. The protesters also demanded an increase of minimum wage from US$365 to US$500, respect for workers' rights, and the release of innocent people captured during the gang crackdown. On 15 September, various organizations and civil movements held another protest march against re-election. The march traveled from the Rosales Hospital to the Plaza Gerardo Barrios. According to Francisco Omar Parada, a spokesman for the Resistance and Popular Rebellion Bloc, the march protested presidential re-election, the reductions of municipalities and seats on the Legislative Assembly, the "destruction" ("{{lang|es|destrucci√≥n}}") of democratic institutions, and the "illegal control" ("{{lang|es|control ilegal}}") exerted by the presidency, the judiciary, the Office of the Attorney General, and other state institutions. The presidential candidates for ARENA, the FMLN, and {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} participated in the protest, as did various opposition deputies of the Legislative Assembly.<ref name="15pro" />

sentences.text: In October and November 2023, a total of ten formal requests were submitted to the TSE calling for the body to not register Bukele's presidential candidacy or void his candidacy after he initiated the registration process. {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}, ARENA, and various NGOs filed these requests. On 9 November, the TSE reaffirmed that Bukele's candidacy was legal and dismissed all the petitions to void his candidacy.

sentences.text: Vice President of El Salvador|Vice President F√©lix Ulloa, who supports Bukele's re-election bid, had suggested that Bukele should seek a leave of absence or express permission from the Supreme Court six months before the election. In April 2023, Ulloa stated that Bukele was seeking a "second mandate" ("{{lang|es|segundo mandato}}") rather than re-election, adding that, while immediate re-election was prohibited by the constitution, a second mandate was not. Some politicians, including Ulloa, also suggested that Bukele should resign six months before the election to be able to legally pursue re-election, but according to constitutional lawyer Enrique Anaya, resigning would have annulled Bukele's legal immunity and allow him to be prosecuted for alleged corruption and human rights violations. Other constitutional lawyers state that his re-election campaign would be unconstitutional regardless. Ulloa and {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}' deputy Christian Guevara stated that both Bukele and Ulloa would resign before 1 December 2023, six months before their second inauguration if they win re-election, and that a successor would be designated as president. On 28 November, Bukele announced he would ask for a leave of absence from the Legislative Assembly on 1 December to relieve him of his duties as president to focus on his presidential election campaign. Bukele was granted a leave of absence on 30 November and Claudia Rodr√≠guez de Guevara, his private secretary, was named as presidential designee; she assumed office the following day and her appointment was criticized as unconstitutional by analysts and lawyers.

sentences.text: On 18 January 2023, the Legislative Assembly passed a resolution to increase the criminal penalty for electoral fraud to 15‚Äì20 years in prison from the previous penalty of 4‚Äì6 years. If the individual was a gang member, the penalty was increased further to 20‚Äì30 years of imprisonment. On 16 February, the Legislative Assembly passed a law making it illegal to impede the registration process for electoral candidates. According to the updated penal code, impeding a candidate's registration process is legally considered electoral fraud and would result in 6‚Äì20 years of imprisonment. Lawyers and electoral experts alleged that the updated law would be used against those who opposed Bukele's re-election campaign; Eduardo Escobar and Ruth Eleonora L√≥pez, the chief of anti-corruption committee for {{ill|Cristosal|es}}, claimed that it was intimidation and a threat.

sentences.text: In addition to the {{Ill|Unique Identity Document|es|Documento √önico de Identidad}} (DUI; the primary identity document for Salvadorans), TSE magistrates {{ill|Julio Olivo|es|Julio Olivo}} and Dora Mart√≠nez de Barahona suggested using biometrics, specifically Fingerprint#Fingerprint identification|fingerprinting, to ensure election security. The Office for the Defense of Human Rights, a Salvadoran governmental agency, was an Election monitoring|observer for the 2024 elections. In March 2023, {{Lang|es|Votante|italic=no}}, a voter's initiative created by five Salvadoran civil society organizations, petitioned the TSE to allow the United Nations, the Organization of American States (OAS), and the European Union (EU) to monitor the elections. On 26 March, the TSE began the process of accepting international observers to monitor the election, anticipating that almost 5,800 national and international observers to monitor the election. In September 2023, the TSE officially accepted the OAS and the EU as election monitors for the 2024 election process; the OAS accepted the TSE's offer while the EU stated that it would support the electoral process. Isabel Saint Malo, a former Vice President of Panama|vice president of Panama, was the head of the OAS election observation mission. In October 2023, the TSE announced that it had signed an agreement with Mexico's Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education to audit the expatriate electronic voting process and another agreement with CGTS Corp. to audit both the expatriate electronic voting process and the expatriate electoral registry.

sentences.text: On 18 October 2022, the Legislative Assembly passed the Special Law for the Exercise of Suffrage Abroad, which allowed Right of expatriates to vote in their country of origin|Salvadorans living outside of the country to vote electronically in the presidential and legislative elections, but not the municipal or PARLACEN elections. The TSE announced on 17 November 2022 that it would guarantee the right of Salvadorans abroad to vote in the 2024 election. According to the TSE, a total of 685,026 Salvadoran expatriates in 53 countries were eligible to vote {{As of|2023|August|19|lc=y}}. Under the electoral law, their votes would be counted as part of San Salvador Department. Some opposition figures claimed that the law would lead to Electoral fraud|voter fraud, while Castro rejected the notion that fraud would occur in the expatriate voting process.

sentences.text: Per the Law of Political Parties, the TSE did not monitor the political parties' primary elections for irregularities. In June 2023, some members of {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} claimed that there were irregularities present in the party's primary elections. They criticized the party for presenting single-candidate primaries and promoting Bukele's family members for municipal races. On 1 July, {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}' National Electoral Commission announced that it would open an internal investigation to guarantee that the party's statutes and regulations were followed and that those who attempted to manipulate the electoral process would be punished and turned over to the country's legal system. On 31 July, {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} suspended Rebeca Santos's legislative candidacy after videos surfaced allegedly showing Santos's staffers soliciting party members for codes to vote in her favor. On 30 June 2023, Mayra Zetino, the mayor of Sacacoyo and a member of GANA, announced her departure from GANA, claiming that there was a lack of transparency and low confidence in the party's primary election process. Guillermo Gallegos, the vice president of GANA and a deputy of the Legislative Assembly, responded to Zetino's announcement by stating that there were no irregularities within the party.

sentences.text: According to a UFG opinion poll conducted in May and June 2023, 62.8 percent of Salvadorans believed the elections would be "clean and transparent" ("{{lang|es|limpias y transparentes}}"), 25 percent had doubts about the election's legitimacy, and 9.7 percent believed there would be fraud. A poll conducted by the Central American University, San Salvador|Central American University in November 2023 found that 45.2 percent of Salvadorans believed that the elections would be "clean" ("{{lang|es|limpias}}"), while 31.5 percent believed there would be fraud.

content.title: Reduction of municipalities and legislative seats

sentences.text: On 30 December 2022, Bukele tweeted that he believed the country's 262 municipalities should be reduced to only 50, claiming that it was "absurd that 21,000 km<sup>2</sup> are divided into 262 municipalities" ("{{lang|es|absurdo que 21,000 kms<sup>2</sup> est√©n divididos en 262 alcald√≠as}}").{{efn|21,000 km<sup>2</sup> is approximately 8,100 sq mi.}} Various economists, lawyers, and politicians argued that the proposed reduction was an attempt to consolidate power through gerrymandering, would grant {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} an electoral advantage, and would lead to data manipulation to favor the government. Eugenio Chicas, a former TSE magistrate TSE, denounced the idea, claiming that it was a part of Bukele's "political vision" to consolidate a military dictatorship.

sentences.text: Gallegos expressed his support for Bukele's proposal, adding that he believed the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly should also be reduced. Ulloa supported reducing the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly and suggested decreasing it from 84 to 50 seats. In February 2023, Castro confirmed that {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} was considering reducing the number of deputies in the Legislative Assembly from 84 to 64 and the number of municipalities from 252 to 50.

sentences.text: Johnny Wright Sol|John Wright, a {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} deputy, described the proposal to reduce the number of deputies as "extremely irresponsible" for occurring within one year of the election. Claudia Ortiz criticized the announcement, stating the proposed reforms could help {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} form a one-party state. She also argued that the time to make electoral reforms had passed and that the changes would violate Article 291-A of the electoral code, On 15 March 2023, the Legislative Assembly voted to repeal Article 291-A, which ARENA deputy Ren√© Portillo Cuadra described as unconstitutional. and the Washington Office on Latin America, a U.S. non-governmental organization, described as "the latest backstep in the country".

sentences.text: In February 2023, GANA deputy Newman Salgado claimed that the country's population would support the reductions of Assembly deputies and municipalities. According to a Fundaungo poll in March 2023, 48.8 percent of Salvadorans supported reducing the number of municipalities, while 44.2 opposed it. Meanwhile, 80.2 percent supported reducing the number of legislative seats, while only 16.4 opposed it. A May 2023 poll conducted by UFG found that 66.4 percent supported the reduction of municipalities while 39.4 percent opposed it. A later Fundaungo poll in September 2023 found that 66.9 percent of Salvadorans supported the reduction of municipalities while 27.4 percent opposed it.

references.text: <ref name="LPG64" /> According to a poll conducted by the Francisco Gavidia University that month, around 48.5 percent of Salvadorans erroneously believed that El Salvador was already divided into only 50 municipalities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/encuesta-ufg-la-mitad-de-salvadorenos-cree-que-el-pais-tiene-50-municipios|title=Encuesta UFG: la Mitad de Salvadore√±os Cree que el Pa√≠s Tiene 50 Municipios|trans-title=UFG Poll: Half of Salvadorans Believe that the Country has 50 Municipalities|language=es|date=21 February 2023|access-date=21 February 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|archive-date=21 February 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230221144401/https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/encuesta-ufg-la-mitad-de-salvadorenos-cree-que-el-pais-tiene-50-municipios|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: During a speech celebrating his fourth year in office on 1 June 2023, Bukele formally proposed legislation to reduce the number of municipalities from 262 to 44 and the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly from 84 to 60. Regarding the municipal reduction, he stated that the present municipalities would be transformed into districts, adding that municipal employees would keep their jobs and that communities would still be able to celebrate their local traditions and customs. Bukele argued that the reduction would also reduce the budgetary burden on the municipalities, make a "more equitable" distribution of taxation possible, and make electing and auditing mayors easier. Regarding the legislative reduction, he stated that the number of seats would return to the number that were present before the 1992 Chapultepec Peace Accords. He criticized opposition politicians, stating "this Assembly once had 60 deputies, it did not occur to us this government that those in the corner do not like this announcement because ARENA and the FMLN, in that farce they signed, added 24 more deputies and it was the only thing that they accomplished in those 'peace accords'" ("{{lang|es|esta Asamblea ten√≠a 60 diputados, no se nos ocurri√≥ en este Gobierno, a esos de la esquina no les gusta este anuncio porque ARENA y el FMLN en esa farsa que firmaron a√±adieron a 24 diputados m√°s y fue lo √∫nico que cumplieron en esos 'acuerdos de paz'}}").

sentences.text: ARENA stated that the reductions were a "tactic to swing the electoral field in [{{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}'] favor" ("{{lang|es|t√°ctica para inclinar la cancha electoral a su favor}}"). Claudia Ortiz stated that the reduction of municipalities was to benefit {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}' mayors who had done a "very bad job" since their election in 2021. Marleni Funes, an FMLN deputy, claimed that Bukele wanted to guarantee his grip on power and that every Salvadoran knows that fewer resources would arrive when the municipalities were reduced. √ìscar Ortiz (Salvadoran politician)|√ìscar Ortiz, the secretary-general of the FMLN, described the proposals as "institutional fraud" for occurring during the lead up to the 2024 election.

sentences.text: On 7 June 2023, the Legislative Assembly approved the proposal to reduce the Legislative Assembly from 84 to 60 seats. Anabel Belloso, an FMLN deputy, claimed that the purpose of the legislative reduction was to "continue concentrating power", and other opposition figures argued that the reduction would diminish the smaller parties' political participation. In contrast, GANA deputy Romeo A√ºerbach denied that the reductions would affect the representation of smaller parties. Claudia Ortiz and ARENA deputy C√©sar Reyes claimed that the reduction would assure and concentrate more power for {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}.

sentences.text: On 13 June 2023, the Legislative Assembly approved the proposal to reduce the number of municipalities from 262 to 44, with the proposal stipulating that the reductions would go into effect on 1 May 2024. Portillo Cuadra described the reductions as "counterproductive" as it would assign mayors to oversee more people in each municipality. Wright claimed that the reductions would concentrate power among fewer people and that municipal representation was becoming "less democratic". He claimed that the municipal reductions were electoral objectives rather than a desire to promote development or save money and questioned the lack of studies conducted to determine if the 262 municipalities should be reduced to 44. In response to the opposition's criticism, Castro claimed that the political opposition was becoming desperate because the country was returning to a "fair system".

sentences.text: General elections were scheduled to be held in El Salvador five years after the 2019 presidential election and three years after the 2021 legislative election. The president, vice president, 60 Legislative Assembly deputies, 44 mayors and municipal councils of the country's municipalities (second-level subdivisions), and 20 Central American Parliament deputies were elected through a Direct election|popular vote. El Salvador's constitution mandated that the election would be "free, direct, equal and Secret ballot|secret". On 11 August 2022, the Supreme Electoral Court announced that the elections for the presidency, vice presidency, and the Legislative Assembly would be held on Sunday, 4 February 2024, and that the elections for the 44 municipalities and the Central American Parliament would be held on Sunday, 3 March 2024. If a second presidential round had been necessary, it would have occurred on 3 March. Voting was held from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. Central Time Zone|Central Standard Time.

sentences.text: To win the presidential election, a candidate needs an Majority|absolute majority (50%{{Nbsp}}+{{Nbsp}}1). If no candidate received an absolute majority, a Two-round system|second round between the two candidates with the most valid votes would have occurred within 30 days of the first round. Deputies of the Legislative Assembly were elected by the D'Hondt method, which was changed in June 2023 from the hare quota largest remainders method used in previous elections. Meanwhile, mayors, municipal council members, and Central American Parliament deputies were elected by open list proportional representation. The 60 deputies of the Legislative Assembly were elected in 14 constituencies for the Departments of El Salvador|country's 14 departments (first-level subdivisions), the 44 mayors and municipal councils were elected for each constituency, and the 20 Central American Parliament deputies were elected from one nationwide constituency.<ref name="constitution" /><ref name="Nohlen" />

sentences.text: Presidential and vice presidential candidates must be at least 30 years old, legislative candidates must be at least 25 years old, and municipal candidates must be at least 21 years old. All candidates must be Salvadoran citizens by birth. Per article 38 of the Law of Political Parties, at least 30 percent of a party's total candidates for the legislative, municipal, and PARLACEN elections must be women. In addition to the 60 deputies elected to the Legislative Assembly and the 20 deputies elected to PARLACEN (referred to as proprietary deputies), an additional 60 substitute deputies were elected to the Legislative Assembly and 20 substitute deputies were elected to PARLACEN. Voters in each of the 44 municipalities elected 1 mayor and a varying number of members to the municipal council. Each municipal council consisted of 1 trustee, 4 proprietary aldermen, and 4 substitute alderman, however, two municipalities elected 8 proprietary alderman and two more elected 10 proprietary alderman due to those municipalities' larger size. In total, 624 people were elected to hold public office in the 2024 elections, a decrease from 3,206 in 2021.

sentences.text: A total of 1,595 voting centers were available across the country. Voting was not compulsory. Electronic voting for Salvadoran expatriates began at midnight on 6 January 2024. Expatriates were able to vote at 81 voting centers in 60 of the List of diplomatic missions of El Salvador|country's embassies and consulates in 30 countries; 42 eligible voters in 22 countries were unable to vote. The designs for all four ballots‚Äîpresidential, legislative, municipal, and PARLACEN‚Äîwere finalized on 6 December 2023.

sentences.text: In December 2022, TSE magistrate Noel Orellana estimated that it would cost between US$25 and 30 million to finance the expatriate vote for the 2024 election, but later revised the estimate to US$120 million. In February 2023, the TSE announced that the expatriate vote would cost US$70.6 million and the national election would cost US$89 million, for a total cost of US$159.7 million for the 2024 election. In March 2023, the TSE reduced its estimate to US$129.3 million and formally requested that amount from the Legislative Assembly. The Legislative Assembly approved the TSE's request on 15 March 2023, making the 2024 election the most expensive election in Salvadoran history.

sentences.text: On 10 June 2023, the TSE announced that it came to an agreement with El Salvador Products and Services Exchange (BOLPROS) regarding procurement procedures for the election. On 20 June, the TSE announced that it had signed an agreement with the National Charity Lottery (LNB) regarding the verification of financial information of political parties. Through the agreement, the TSE was able to compare the financial information the political parties presented, with the LNB handling the data. On 29 June, the TSE announced that it had contracted Indra Solutions to implement electronic voting.

sentences.text: Additionally, various civil movements attempted to register with the TSE to gain political party status and to run in the 2024 election. Such civil movements included Citizen Power, the Authentic Republican Movement, the Authentic Salvadoran Movement (MAS), We Shall Construct a New El Salvador, the Salvadoran Veteran Party, Somos, and i. Citizen Power announced its primary elections in March 2023, but the TSE declared the announcement invalid because they were not registered to participate in the 2024 election. In mid-April 2023, the party turned in 50,000 signatures to the TSE to be registered as a political party. MAS abandoned its efforts to register in early-April 2023. In late-2022, Paul Monroy, the leader of i, announced the movement abandoned its efforts to register with the TSE.

sentences.text: Salvadoran citizens over the age of 18 living in El Salvador had until 7 August 2023 to register to vote, while those living outside of the country had until 5 November 2023 to register. Salvadorans in the country had until 3 April 2023 to change their address of residency on their Unique Identity Document, while those living abroad had until 5 November 2023. Guillermo Wellman, a magistrate of the TSE, stated that individuals arrested during the country's gang crackdown were ineligible to vote. In the legislative election, votes cast from outside of the country were counted towards selecting deputies in the department of San Salvador Department|San Salvador. There were a total of 6,214,399 registered voters.<ref name="Final Results P"/>

sentences.text: {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} held a majority in the List of members of the XIII Legislative Assembly of El Salvador|13th Legislative Assembly; GANA, the PDC, and the PCN supported {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}' government. The opposition consisted of ARENA, the FMLN, {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}, and {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}}. Within the Central American Parliament, the fifteen deputies from {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} and GANA belong to the Center-Democratic Integration Group, the four deputies from ARENA and the PCN belong to the Integrationist Democratic Unity, and the sole FMLN deputy belongs to the Parliamentary Group of the Left.

sentences.text: The TSE mandated that the parties had to announce their primary elections by 5 March 2023. The TSE initially required that the parties hold their primary elections by 5 July 2023, but after the Legislative Assembly voted to reduce the number of municipalities in June 2023, the TSE delayed the deadline for primary elections until 20 July 2023. Political parties had until 7 August 2023 to register presidential and legislative coalitions. Parties had until 4 September 2023 to form municipal and PARLACEN coalitions. In total, there were 7 presidential candidates, 7 vice presidential candidates, 313 legislative candidates, 202 municipal candidates, and 80 PARLACEN candidates. According to Citizen Action, only 67,415‚Äîor 26.4 percent‚Äîof registered political party members voted in the country's primary elections, the lowest percentage since the organization had been keeping track of this statistic since the 2015 Salvadoran legislative election|2015 primary elections.

sentences.text: Before the campaign period began, some {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} politicians began to promote their electoral campaigns on Twitter and others purchased online advertising through Google Ads. L√≥pez criticized the campaigns as illegal, arguing they violated article 172 of the electoral code. Legal experts and opposition politicians also accused {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} of "promoting the figure of Nayib Bukele" ahead of the 3 October 2023 campaigning period for presidential candidates, and called on the TSE to take action against the supposed early campaigns being undertaken by {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}. In October 2023, the TSE stated that it was investigating 20 to 25 cases of early campaigns. On 4 February 2024, four days after the beginning of a period of election silence, Bukele called upon voters to vote for him; ARENA criticized Bukele's call to voters, denouncing what the party described as "disrespectful of the Constitution and the law".

sentences.text:
{{Nayib Bukele sidebar}}
In February 2023, Castro stated that {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} aimed to win 70 seats in the Legislative Assembly and that the party did not intend to join a coalition with any other party. Following the reduction of municipalities and legislative seats, Castro stated that {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} expected to win all 44 municipalities and all 60 seats in the Legislative Assembly. Castro's revised projections were criticized by opposition leaders; Claudia Ortiz described the projections as "undemocratic", Wright claimed that {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} "consolidating is a dictatorship", and Belloso stated that the party was seeking to "concentrate power".

sentences.text: {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}' deputies held events in the U.S. to meet Salvadoran expatriates and support Bukele's re-election campaign. Eduardo Escobar claimed the events were illegal according to the constitution's rules about promoting candidates. {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} held such events in Houston, Los Angeles, New York City, Uniondale, New York|Uniondale, and Washington, D.C. When Bukele gave a speech to the Legislative Assembly to celebrate his fourth year in office on 1 June 2023, a group of Bukele's supporters were present inside the Legislative Assembly. They held signs with "#Nayib2024" written on them and banners supporting Bukele's re-election. The supporters also cheered for Bukele and the {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} deputies, booed the opposition's deputies, and yelled chants supportive of re-election.

sentences.text: On 25 June 2023, Bukele and Ulloa officially registered their pre-candidacies with {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} for president and vice president, respectively. but after the reduction of the municipalities was approved, the party delayed its primaries until 9 July. According to Castro, the majority of {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}s' deputies were seeking re-election. On 9 July, {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} formalized Bukele and Ulloa's presidential and vice presidential campaigns. They ran unopposed and won 44,398 votes. During the primaries, 60 legislative candidates, and 20 PARLACEN candidates were also confirmed. {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} formed one municipal coalition with GANA for San Miguel Centro and two municipal coalitions with Democratic Change (El Salvador)|Democratic Change for Sonsonate Oeste and Santa Ana Norte.

references.text: <ref name="BULPG" /> In a tweet announcing their registrations, {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} stated that "New Ideas are invincible".<ref name="WPrel2" /> The party originally scheduled its primary elections for 2 July,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/nuevas-ideas-convoca-a-elecciones-para-elegir-candidatos-rumbo-a-2024|title=Nuevas Ideas Convoca a Elecciones para Elegir Candidatos Rumbo a 2024|trans-title=Nuevas Ideas Convokes Elections to Elect Candidates on the Path to 2024|language=es|date=5 March 2023|access-date=5 March 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Ver√≥nica|last1=Cresp√≠n|archive-date=6 March 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230306011442/https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/nuevas-ideas-convoca-a-elecciones-para-elegir-candidatos-rumbo-a-2024|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} began the process of registering its 60 legislative candidates and 20 PARLACEN candidates with the TSE on 20 October 2023, meanwhile, Bukele registered his candidacy with the TSE on 26 October, the last possible day to do so. After Bukele initiated the registration process, he addressed a crowd of supporters outside the TSE building who were chanting phrases such as "five more [years]", "re-election", and "not one step back". The TSE officially approved Bukele and Ulloa's candidacies on 3 November,

sentences.text: Bukele called on his supporters to win a three-fourths majority for {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} in the Legislative Assembly in order to allow him to maintain the gang crackdown during his second term. In a video message, Bukele claimed that if {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} lost only one seat, the opposition would "liberate the gang members and use them to rise to power" ("{{lang|es|liberar a los pandilleros y ocuparlos para llegar al poder}}"), although opposition politicians have denied such claims. In a message posted on social media, Bukele claimed that people who continue to believe in and vote for the opposition "does not see, because they do not want to see; they will not change" ("{{lang|es|no ve, porque no quiere ver; no cambiar√°}}"). Bukele stated that he was willing to work with the international community as long as they respected El Salvador as a partner rather than as subservient, adding that El Salvador could "change".<ref name="BDNM" />

sentences.text: In December 2022, Carlos Garc√≠a Saade, the president of ARENA, stated that ARENA sought to attain the "maximum number" of deputies and mayors, After the reduction of municipalities and legislative seats, Garc√≠a Saade stated that the party sought to win at least 25 seats in the Legislative Assembly and 30 municipalities.

references.text: <ref name="Aspire" /> adding in May 2023 that the party sought to win more than 25 seats in the Legislative Assembly and more than 125 municipalities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/arena-presidente-de-elecciones-2024-alcaldias-/1059797/2023/|title=Presidente de ARENA: "Vamos a Sacar M√°s de 125 Alcald√≠as y M√°s de 25 Diputados"|trans-title=President of ARENA: "We Will Win More than 125 Mayorships and More than 25 Deputies|language=es|date=9 May 2023|access-date=9 May 2023|first1=Jessica|last1=Garc√≠a|work=El Diario de Hoy|archive-date=9 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230509174847/https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/arena-presidente-de-elecciones-2024-alcaldias-/1059797/2023/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 26 October 2022, Garc√≠a Saade announced that the party would not join a coalition with the FMLN to defeat Bukele in the 2024 election. He stated that joining forces with the FMLN would "deteriorate both parties" ("{{lang|es|deteriorar a ambos partidos}}"), and that he wanted ARENA to be the alternative for Salvadorans who oppose Bukele. Although he ruled out a coalition with the FMLN, he was still open to forming a coalition with other parties. At an event inaugurating the party's elected leadership on 26 March 2023, Garc√≠a Saade stated that the party was seeking to form coalitions and that it was looking for someone to lead the country's opposition as an "alternative for El Salvador". On 22 May, ''El Faro (digital newspaper)|El Faro'' alleged that ARENA was in negotiations with the FMLN, {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}}, and {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} to form a political coalition for the presidential election to oppose Bukele. ARENA leaders acknowledged that the party was involved in negotiations but denied that the party was forming a coalition, and Garc√≠a Saade confirmed that ARENA had decided to not form any coalition.

sentences.text: On 9 July 2023, ARENA officially announced that it had selected Joel S√°nchez, a Salvadoran businessman living in the U.S., and Hilcia Bonilla, a businesswoman living in the U.S., as its presidential and vice presidential candidates, respectively. S√°nchez's candidacy was proposed by the Citizen Resistance civil movement on 15 June 2023. Although his initial running mate was Hardy Garc√≠a, the wife of Salvadoran Independent Party (PAIS) leader Roy Garc√≠a; she withdrew her candidacy because she had received "threats". When S√°nchez's candidacy was initially proposed, Miguel Fort√≠n Maga√±a, the leader of Citizen Resistance, hoped that a political party would accept the movement's proposal and allow S√°nchez to run under another party's banner.

sentences.text: ARENA's primary elections were originally scheduled to occur on 18 June 2023, but were later moved to 2 July then again to 9 July, and finally to 16 July. The registration period for primary candidates ended on 15 May. Garc√≠a Saade stated that the presidential pre-candidates' names would not be disclosed for their safety, claiming that they were threatened by persons in government and by governmental institutions. On 16 July, ARENA elected S√°nchez and Bonilla as its presidential and vice presidential candidates, respectively.

sentences.text: On 25 July 2023, S√°nchez stated that he would be willing to renounce his presidential candidacy if it was what "our country and our population wanted" ("{{lang|es|deseo de nuestro pa√≠s y de nuestra poblaci√≥n}}") in order for find a more "suitable" candidate. Following the publication of a UFG opinion poll in late-August 2023 which listed S√°nchez as having 4.3 percent support, Julia Evelyn Mart√≠nez, a former professor at the Central American University (San Salvador)|Central American University, stated that S√°nchez was considering withdrawing his candidacy due to his low polling figures. In September 2023, Garc√≠a Saade stated that he believed that S√°nchez would be able to win the presidency in the second round. ARENA began the process of registering S√°nchez's and Bonilla's candidacies with the TSE on 9 October 2023. By 26 October, party also began to register all of its 60 legislative candidates in all 14 departments. On 23 November, ARENA began to register all of its 20 PARLACEN candidates. The TSE registered S√°nchez and Bonilla's candidacies on 13 November, the legislative candidates by 16 December, and the PARLACEN candidates on 8 January 2024.<ref name="TSEallreg" />

sentences.text: S√°nchez stated that the state of exception "has to be stopped", elaborating that it "opens the opportunity to carry out abuses, corruption, [and] influence peddling". S√°nchez promised to review economic, taxation, educational, and agricultural policies to determine which ones were succeeding and which were failing. He described the Bitcoin in El Salvador|adoption of bitcoin as legal tender as "the worst decision [Bukele's] government could have made", stating that it resulted in the International Monetary Fund refusing to support El Salvador and the government losing millions of dollars. S√°nchez and Bonilla stated that they would promote investment by "establishing a judicial system that works" ("{{lang|es|establecer nuestro sistema jur√≠dico que funcione}}"), and S√°nchez claimed that he was already in talks with potential unspecified investors. S√°nchez supports restoring diplomatic relations with Taiwan as he believes that Taiwan was a "better ally" than China, citing better exchange student programs and trade deals with the country before relations were severed in 2018. He opposes reducing the number of municipalities, arguing that it would result in parts of the country being neglected by mayors. In October 2023, S√°nchez announced that he would upload videos to TikTok that would make Salvadoran youths want to dance in support of his campaign.

sentences.text: Following the conclusion of the FMLN's 42nd Ordinary National Convention on 11 December 2022, √ìscar Ortiz (Salvadoran politician)|√ìscar Ortiz, the secretary-general of the FMLN, announced that the party would not join any coalition in the 2024 elections with {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}, ARENA, or GANA, but the party would be open to forming coalitions with other parties. On 22 May 2023, {{Lang|es|El Faro}} alleged that the FMLN was in negotiations with ARENA, {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}}, and {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} to form a political coalition for the presidential election to oppose Bukele. In July 2023, √Ångel Monge, a member of the FMLN's political commission, stated that the FMLN would not form coalitions for the Legislative Assembly but would still consider forming coalitions for the municipal elections. In October 2023, Marleni Funes stated that the FMLN aimed to win 16 or 17 seats in the Legislative Assembly.

<ref name="El Faro coalition" /> FMLN leaders acknowledged that the party was involved in negotiations<ref name="AFdeny2" /> but denied that the party was forming a coalition, and √ìscar Ortiz reiterated that the party would not form a coalition with ARENA, GANA, or Nuevas Ideas.<ref name="AFdeny" /> Jaime Guevara claimed that all the parties, except for the FMLN, were seeking to unify under a single presidential candidate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/bukele-dice-arena-y-fmln-consuman-su-union-dirigentes-lo-descartan-y-reconocen-platicas-con-organizaciones|title=Bukele Dice ARENA y FMLN "Consuman su Uni√≥n", Dirigentes lo Descartan y Reconocen Pl√°ticas con Organizaciones|trans-title=Bukele Says ARENA and FMLN "Form their Union", Leaders Discard It and Recognize Talks with Organizations|language=es|date=23 May 2023|access-date=24 May 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Yolanda|last1=Maga√±a|archive-date=24 May 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230524032550/https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/bukele-dice-arena-y-fmln-consuman-su-union-dirigentes-lo-descartan-y-reconocen-platicas-con-organizaciones|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 29 May 2023, Flores officially registered as a pre-candidate for the presidency and Werner Marroqu√≠n registered as his running-mate. Flores was the party's only presidential pre-candidate to register, although Jaime Zavaleta expressed interest in securing the party's nomination. The FMLN was open to forming a presidential coalition with {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}}, {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}, and PAIS, but ultimately did not join any presidential coalition.

<ref name="7A4S" /> In October 2023, √ìscar Ortiz assured that the FMLN's candidates represented the "hope and future of the country".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diariolahuella.com/fmln-afirma-que-sus-candidatos-representan-el-futuro-de-el-salvador/|title=FMLN Dice que Sus Candidatos Representan "El Futuro" de El Salvador|trans-title=FMLN Says that Its Candidates Represent "The Future" of El Salvador|language=es|date=5 October 2023|access-date=7 October 2023|work=Diario la Huella|archive-date=12 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231012112424/https://diariolahuella.com/fmln-afirma-que-sus-candidatos-representan-el-futuro-de-el-salvador/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The party originally planned to hold its primary elections on 11 June 2023, but after the reduction of seats in the Legislative Assembly, its primaries were postponed to 2 July and then again to 16 July. On 16 July, Flores and Marroqu√≠n were officially elected as the FMLN's presidential and vice presidential candidates, respectively. The party also elected 44 municipal candidates and 60 candidates for the Legislative Assembly from all 14 departments. According to Citizen Action, the FMLN stated that it would not disclose its entire list of candidates due to alleged threats made against its candidates for participating in the elections. On 23 October, Flores stated that he had responded to the TSE's concerns. The TSE officially voted to register Flores and Marroqu√≠n's candidacies on 3 November. On 28 October, the FMLN began registering its municipal candidates from San Salvador. On 16 November, the party began the process of registering all 20 of its PARLACEN candidates. That same day, √ìscar Ortiz stated that the party would have considered dropping out of the 2024 elections if it was unable to continue financing its electoral campaigns as a result of debts accumulated during the 2019 and 2021 elections. The TSE registered the legislative candidates by 15 December and the PARLACEN candidates on 24 January 2024.<ref name="TSEallreg" />

sentences.text: In October 2023, Flores stated that he believed he would win the presidential election in the first round, making a second round irrelevant. In September 2023, Flores stated that, if elected, he would maintain the state of exception if the country's population supported it. He also stated that all criminals "will continue to stay in prison and we will pursue all criminals". Regarding corruption, Flores stated that "corruption is not combated, corruption is avoided ... in my government, I will not select corrupt individuals to form part of the cabinet" ("{{lang|es|la corrupci√≥n no se combate, la corrupci√≥n se evita ... en mi gobierno no voy a presentar corruptos que formen parte del gabinete}}"). Flores promised to invest US$30 million in the transportation sector and reduce the price of transportation fares for students by half, which would affect around 150,000 students in the country. Flores promised to launch the "Zero Hunger" ("{{lang|es|Hambre Cero}}") initiative to combat hunger by investing US$60 million into building three "zero-hunger supply centers" which would distribute grain. Flores also proposed raising the minimum pension from US$50 per day to US$70 per day. He announced his "Prosperous Municipalities" ("{{lang|es|Municipios Pr√≥speros}}") plan to develop and invest in the country's municipalities. Flores promised to launch investigations into all of Cabinet of Nayib Bukele|Bukele's government officials if elected president.

sentences.text: In March 2023, Andy Failer, the leader of {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}, indicated that the party was open to forming coalitions with other parties On 13 April, during an interview on Channel 21, Failer confirmed that the party would not form a coalition with ARENA or the FMLN but was still considering a coalition with {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}}; {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} expressed disinterest in forming a coalition with {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}.

references.text: <ref name="GS26" /> and confirmed that the party would select presidential and vice presidential candidates.<ref name="Confirm">{{cite web|url=https://www.laprensagrafica.com/elsalvador/Partidos-politicos-se-preparan-para-las-elecciones-20230326-0070.html|title=Partidos Pol√≠ticos se Preparan para las Elecciones|trans-title=Political Parties are Preparing for the Elections|date=27 March 2023|access-date=27 March 2023|first1=Sara√≠|last1=Alas|work=La Prensa Gr√°fica|language=es|archive-date=27 March 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230327224143/https://www.laprensagrafica.com/elsalvador/Partidos-politicos-se-preparan-para-las-elecciones-20230326-0070.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="AFdeny" /> On 22 May, ''El Faro'' alleged that {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} was in negotiations with ARENA, the FMLN, and {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} to form a political coalition for the presidential election to oppose Bukele,<ref name="El Faro coalition" /> but {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} reaffirmed that it would form a coalition with ARENA or the FMLN.<ref name="AFdeny" /> On 26 July, Failer posted on Twitter calling for the formation of a "Democratic National Union" with ARENA and the FMLN for a presidential or legislative coalition, but both ARENA and the FMLN reiterated that they would not form a coalition with each other.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/nt-propone-una-union-democratica-que-responden-arena-y-fmln|title=NT Propone Una Uni√≥n Democr√°tica: ¬øQu√© Responden ARENA y FMLN?|trans-title=NT Proposes a Democratic Union: How Do ARENA and FMLN Respond?|language=es|date=26 July 2023|access-date=26 July 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Yolanda|last1=Maga√±a|archive-date=26 July 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230726201734/https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/nt-propone-una-union-democratica-que-responden-arena-y-fmln|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 31 May 2023, Luis Parada (lawyer)|Luis Parada, a lawyer who resides in the U.S., announced that he was running for president. His candidacy was proposed by Sumar por El Salvador. {{ill|Celia Medrano|es}}, a human rights lawyer, was Parada's running mate. The following day, during an interview with Telecorporaci√≥n Salvadore√±a's {{Lang|es|Frente a Frente}}, Failer confirmed that Parada and Medrano were both running under the banner of {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}, adding that "it's to choose between democracy and dictatorship; if we unite ourselves behind this, we will change what is happening to our country". Parada had previously sought ARENA's 2019 presidential nomination.

sentences.text: The party originally planned to hold its primary elections for president and vice president on 25 June 2023 and its primary elections for deputies and mayors on 2 July, but after the reduction of municipalities, the party decided to hold all its primary elections on 15 July. According to Sof√≠a Gonz√°lez, the president of {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}'s permanent electoral commission, {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} would contest legislative seats in 8 departments and the mayorships of 19 municipalities. The party did not participate in the PARLACEN elections as it believed that PARLACEN is a waste of the government's resources. On 15 July, {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} held its primary elections and officially elected Parada and Medrano as its presidential and vice presidential candidates, respectively, awarding them 100 percent of the vote. The party also elected 18 municipal candidates and 40 deputy candidates in seven departments.<ref name="NTconfirm" />

sentences.text: In an interview with Channel 9 in July 2023, Parada stated that, if elected, he would review the necessity and constitutionality of the state of exception. In August 2023, Parada stated that he would suspend the state of exception, describing it as "nothing more than the current government's propaganda", and an "illusion". Parada promised to remove the justices on the Supreme Court's Constitutional Court and restore the justices that the Legislative Assembly removed on 1 May 2021.

sentences.text: Solidary Force originally scheduled its primary elections for 2 July 2023, but after the reduction of the municipalities, its primaries were delayed for 16 July. On 31 March, the TSE officially allowed the party to participate in the elections. The party announced its elections again on 7 April, as its the TSE considered the original announcement invalid. Some deputies from ARENA, the FMLN, {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}}, and {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} criticized the TSE for allowing the Solidary Force to register, describing the process as favoritism and illegal.

sentences.text: On 16 July 2023, Solidary Force held its primary elections for the 44 municipalities, 16 deputies for San Salvador, and 1 deputy for each Ahuachap√°n Department|Ahuachap√°n, La Paz Department (El Salvador)|La Paz, Santa Ana Department|Santa Ana, and Sonsonate Department|Sonsonate. On 24 July, Solidary Force announced that Javier Renderos, an Obstetrics|obstetrician, would be its presidential candidate and that Rafael Montalvo (politician)|Rafael Montalvo, an agriculturist and former ARENA deputy of the Legislative Assembly, would be its vice presidential candidate. Solidary Force formed a municipal coalition with Democratic Change for Usulut√°n Oeste.<ref name="MUNcoa" />

references.text: <ref name="6primaries" /> Rigoberto Soto, Solidary Force's leader, stated that the party would complete is primary elections for the remaining departments' deputies by 19 July,<ref name="19Jul" /> and also stated that the party could still select a presidential candidate by the same date. He added that the party would be open to forming coalitions with other parties except for with ARENA or the FMLN.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/fuerza-solidaria-no-descarta-presentar-candidatura-a-presidente-para-2024|title=Fuerza Solidaria no Descarta Presentar Candidatura a Presidente para 2024|trans-title=Solidary Force Does Not Dismiss Presenting a Candidacy for President for 2024|language=es|date=16 July 2023|access-date=16 July 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Leonardo|last1=Cer√≥n}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 23 October 2023, Solidary Force began the process of registering its presidential and vice presidential candidates as well as its legislative candidates for San Salvador. By 26 October, the party had initiated the process of registering its legislative candidates in nine departments.<ref name="26OctReg1" /> On 23 November, the party began the process of registering all 20 of its PARLACEN candidates.<ref name="PFCpar" /> The TSE registered Renderos and Montalvo's candidacies on 13 November, the legislative candidates by 8 December, and the PARLACEN candidates by 30 January 2024.<ref name="TSEallreg" />

sentences.text: The Salvadoran Patriotic Fraternity held its primary elections from 16 to 20 July 2023. On 27 August, the party announced that it selected Marina Murillo, an architect, as its presidential candidate and Fausto Carranza as its vice presidential candidate.

references.text: <ref name="disclose">{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/algunos-partidos-politicos-no-hicieron-publicas-sus-elecciones-internas|title=Algunos Partidos Pol√≠ticos no Hicieron P√∫blicas sus Elecciones Internas|trans-title=Some Political Parties Have Not Their Primary Elections Public|language=es|date=25 July 2023|access-date=25 July 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Ver√≥nica|last1=Cresp√≠n}}</ref>

<ref name="FPScand" /> Murillo is the first woman to run for president of El Salvador since Rina Escalante ran with the Authentic Democratic Christian Movement in the 1994 Salvadoran general election|1994 presidential election.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/presidente-presidencia-de-la-republica-elecciones-2024-participacion-politica-mujer-/1085853/2023/|title=Una Mujer Busca ser Presidenta de El Salvador, No Pasaba Desde 1994|trans-title=A Woman Seeks to be the President of El Salvador, Has Not Happened Since 1994|language=es|date=27 August 2023|access-date=28 August 2023|work=El Diario de Hoy|first1=Jessica|last1=Guzm√°n}}</ref>

It did not register any legislative candidates.<ref name="26OctReg1" /> On 23 November, the party began to register all 20 of its PARLACEN candidates.<ref name="23Nov" /> The TSE registered Murillo and Carranza's candidacies on 3 November.<ref name="TSEallreg" />

Awad invited Mario Vega (pastor)|Mario Vega, the senior pastor of Misi√≥n Cristiana Elim Internacional, to be his vice presidential candidate, but Vega declined Awad's offer and stated that he did not intend to seek any public office during the 2024 election.<ref name="Vega" /> On 4 June 2023, Awad officially announced his withdrawal from the 2024 election as he did not believe that conditions were favorable for his campaign, but he stated that he would prepare for a new presidential campaign in 2029.<ref name="Awad" />

sentences.text: PAIS planned to hold its elections on 11 June 2023,

references.text: <ref name="primarydelay" /> but Roy Garc√≠a contrarily claimed that the party would not hold elections and instead participate as a social movement in a coalition with another party.<ref name="PAISno" /><ref name="PAISno2" /> After the reduction of municipalities, the party postponed its primaries until 2 July,<ref name="primarydelay" /> but the party ended up holding its primary elections on 16 July. On 16 August, the party sought to hold a meeting with the TSE to discuss the party's status ahead of the 2024 election as the party believed that the TSE showed a lack of recognition of its primary elections. The party stated that it would hold a street protest if the TSE failed to meet with PAIS within eight days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/partido-pais-pide-audiencia-en-el-tse-o-se-tomaran-las-calles-aseguran-afiliados/1083210/2023/|title=Partido PAIS Pide Audiencia en el TSE "o se Tomar√°n las Calles", Aseguran Afiliados|trans-title=PAIS Party Asks for Meeting with the TSE "or We Will Take the Streets"|language=es|date=16 August 2023|access-date=17 August 2023|work=El Diario de Hoy|first1=Jessica|last1=Garc√≠a}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 28 August 2023, PAIS deputy secretary Carlos Molina announced that it selected Jos√© Cardoza, an agricultural engineer, as its presidential candidate and Irma Sosa as its vice presidential candidate. The party also presented its legislative, municipal, and PARLACEN candidates, however, Roy Garc√≠a stated on Facebook that Molina's announcement was not legitimate and that all of the party's candidates were invalid. He added that the party should wait and reorganize for the 2027 legislative election. On 21 September, PAIS began the process of registering Cardoza's and Sosa's candidacies with the TSE, however, on 4 October, the TSE passed a resolution to deregister the party and bar it from participating in the 2024 election. On 13 October, Herbert Vega Cruz, a lawyer for PAIS, accused the TSE magistrates of committing electoral fraud for deregistering the party and rejecting its candidates. By 26 October, PAIS began the process of registering all its legislative candidates in nine departments. On 28 November, the TSE stated that it would not register any of PAIS's presidential, legislative, municipal, or PARLACEN candidates.

sentences.text: In December 2022, Gallegos stated that the party sought to increase the number of seats it had in the Legislative Assembly from 5 to 15. Before the reduction of municipalities' legislative seats, Gallegos stated that the party sought to increase its number of mayors from 34 to over 100. Gallegos initially stated he would seek re-election to the Legislative Assembly, but then later stated that he was running for mayor of San Salvador Centro, and then again reverted his decision again stating that he would be seeking re-election to the Legislative Assembly.

sentences.text: Prior to Bukele's registration as a presidential pre-candidate with Nuevas Ideas on 26 June 2023, some GANA leaders believed that Bukele could seek re-election with GANA rather than Nuevas Ideas as he was initially elected in 2019 as a member of GANA. In July 2022, Gallegos stated that GANA would endorse Bukele's re-election campaign if he ran under the banner of another party instead of GANA. On 16 June 2023, Gallegos stated that GANA would not participate in the presidential election unless Bukele was the party's candidate. On 26 June, Gallegos confirmed that GANA would not run a presidential or vice presidential candidate, stating that the party supports Bukele's re-election campaign.<ref name="GANABRE" />

sentences.text: The party originally planned to hold its primary elections on 2 July 2023, but after the reduction of municipalities, the party delayed its primaries until 16 July. The party held its primaries on 16 July and elected 44 municipal candidates, 60 deputies to the Legislative Assembly from all 14 departments, and deputies to PARLACEN. GANA formed one municipal coalition with {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} for San Miguel Centro and one municipal coalition with the PCN for Chalatenango Centro.<ref name="MUNcoa" /> Unlike in the 2021 election, GANA did not form coalitions with {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} for the Legislative Assembly elections.<ref name="GANANHC" />

sentences.text: Before the reduction of municipalities' legislative seats, Manuel Rodr√≠guez stated that the National Coalition Party (El Salvador)|National Coalition Party ({{Lang|es|Partido de Concertaci√≥n Nacional|italic=no}}, or PCN) sought to increase the number of deputies in the Legislative Assembly from three to nine and increase the number of mayors from 2 to 33.

sentences.text: The party originally planned to hold its primary elections on 5 July 2023, but after the reduction of municipalities, it delayed its primaries to 16 July. The PCN formed a coalition with the Christian Democratic Party ({{Lang|es|Partido Dem√≥crata Cristiano|italic=no}}, or PDC) to jointly contest both legislative seats of Moraz√°n Department|Moraz√°n. It also formed a coalition with the Citizen Power civil movement for legislative seats and municipalities in San Salvador. The coalition is unofficial as Citizen Power is not a registered political party. In August 2023, Rodr√≠guez confirmed that the PCN would not present a presidential candidate. On 30 January 2024, the PCN announced its support for Bukele's presidential campaign.<ref name="PCNBE" /> The PCN formed one municipal coalition with GANA for Chalatenango Centro and two municipal coalitions with the PDC for the Moraz√°n Norte and Moraz√°n Sur.<ref name="MUNcoa" />

sentences.text: On 5 June 2023, Reinaldo Carballo, the Christian Democratic Party (El Salvador)|Christian Democratic Party's (PDC) secretary-general, announced that the party would not have a presidential candidate. He confirmed that the party would participate in the legislative and municipal elections, and that the party was reorganizing its electoral process to adjust for the reduction of municipalities and seats in the Legislative Assembly. After the reduction of municipalities and legislative seats, Carballo stated that the party expects to win at least 10 municipalities and 12 seats in the Legislative Assembly.

sentences.text: The PDC originally planned to hold its primary elections on 14 May 2023, but later postponed them to 2 July and then again to 20 July.

references.text: <ref name="LPGpostpone" /> The party opened its primaries four days early on 16 July<ref name="6primaries" /> and closed them on 19 July.<ref name="19Jul" /> Carballo reaffirmed that the PDC would not have a presidential candidate and stated that the party supported Bukele's re-election campaign.<ref name="PDCBRE" /> The PDC formed a coalition with the PCN to jointly contest both of Moraz√°n's legislative,<ref name="PDCPCNcoa" /> as well as the seats for both the Moraz√°n Norte and Moraz√°n Sur municipalities.<ref name="MUNcoa" /> The PDC disclosed its full list of 20 legislative, 23 municipal, and 2 PARLACEN candidates on 24 September. Carballo reaffirmed that the PDC would not present a presidential candidate, stating "we have not found a Salvadoran who could beat Nayib Bukele".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/pdc-dice-no-llevara-candidato-presidencial-2024-y-presenta-a-sus-candidatos-a-diputados-y-alcaldes|title=PDC Dice no Llevar√° Candidato Presidencial 2024 y Presenta a Sus Candidatos a Diputados y Alcaldes|trans-title=PDC Says It Will Not Present a 2024 Presidential Candidate and Presents Its Candidates for Deputies and Mayors|language=es|date=24 September 2023|access-date=25 September 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Jaqueline|last1=Villeda}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 5 March 2023, {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} formally announced that it would not run a presidential candidate or compete in the PARLACEN elections. Claudia Ortiz announced her intention to be re-elected as a deputy of the Legislative Assembly and that she would not seek a presidential candidacy. Sof√≠a Vaquerano, the party's legal secretary, stated that {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} would not form coalitions with individuals who had been accused of being corrupt.

sentences.text: Initially, Claudia Ortiz stated that the party was open to forming a coalition with other parties, On 22 May 2023, {{Lang|es|El Faro}} alleged that {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} was in negotiations with ARENA, the FMLN, and {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} to form a political coalition for the presidential election to oppose Bukele.<ref name="El Faro coalition" /> In response, {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} stated that it would focus more on the Legislative Assembly than on winning the presidency.<ref name="AFdeny" />

references.text: <ref name="GS26" /> but later stated that the party would not seek any political coalition.<ref name="Vno">{{cite web|url=https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/claudia-ortiz-vamos-selecciones-nacionales-elecciones-legislativas-municipales-presidenciales-primarias-/1050111/2023/|title=Vamos no Presentar√° Candidato para la Presidencia en 2024, dice Claudia Ortiz|trans-title=Vamos Will Not Present a Candidate for the Presidency in 2024|date=28 March 2023|access-date=28 March 2023|language=es|first1=Jessica|last1=Garc√≠a|work=El Diario de Hoy}}</ref>

Additionally, Cesia Rivas was elected as the party's new secretary general.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/partido-vamos-presenta-su-lista-de-candidatos-para-2024|title=Partido Vamos Presenta su Lista de Candidatos para 2024|trans-title=Vamos Party Presents Its List of Candidates for 2024|language=es|date=16 July 2023|access-date=16 July 2023|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Ver√≥nica|last1=Cresp√≠n}}</ref>

sentences.text: Democratic Change (El Salvador)|Democratic Change initially planned to hold its primary elections on 4 June 2023, but later rescheduled them for 19 July.<ref name="19Jul" /> Democratic Change held its primary elections from 16 to 19 July and elected legislative, municipal, and PARLACEN candidates.<ref name="disclose" /> Democratic Change formed two municipal coalitions with {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} for Sonsonate Oeste and Santa Ana Norte and one municipal coalition with Solidary Force for Usulut√°n Oeste.<ref name="MUNcoa" /> On 26 October, the party registered all its legislative candidates in 13 departments.<ref name="26Oct" /> By 23 November, the party began the process of registering all 20 of its PARLACEN candidates.<ref name="PFCpar" /> The TSE registered the legislative candidates by 29 December and the PARLACEN candidates on 24 January 2024.<ref name="TSEallreg" /> Democratic Change did not select a presidential candidate, instead endorsing Bukele's re-election campaign.<ref name="MGTV" />

sentences.text: Various groups such as CIESCA, Fundaungo, {{Lang|es|La Prensa Gr√°fica}}, TResearch, and UFG conducted opinion polling prior to the 2024 general election; virtually every poll indicated significant leads for {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} in the presidential, legislative, and municipal elections. Additionally, opinion polling was conducted to ask whether Salvadorans supported Bukele's re-election; virtually every poll indicated that a large majority of Salvadorans would support Bukele's re-election. Many Salvadoran Americans also supported Bukele's re-election.

sentences.text: The TSE published the presidential election's final results on 9 February 2024 and formally ratified the results on 17 February; Bukele won with 84.65 percent of the vote. Bukele was the first presidential candidate in Salvadoran history to receive more than two million votes. Among the other candidates, Flores received 6.40 percent of the vote, S√°nchez received 5.57 percent, Parada received 2.04 percent, and Renderos and Murillo each received less than 1 percent.<ref name="Final Results P" />

sentences.text: The TSE published the legislative election's final results on 18 February; {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} won 54 out of 60 seats, a supermajority. ARENA and the PCN both won two seats while {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}} and the PDC each won one seat. The FMLN, GANA, and {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} lost all of their seats in the Legislative Assembly, while the Democratic Change and Solidary Force parties failed to win any seats. Additionally, {{Lang|es|Nuestro Tiempo|italic=no}} and Democratic Change failed to receive more than 50,000 votes and could possibly lose registration with the TSE per article 47, section C of the Law of Political Parties, which mandates the dissolution of such parties.

references.text: <ref name="LPGmunres">{{cite web|url=https://www.laprensagrafica.com/elsalvador/Sin-reestructuracion-municipal-Nuevas-Ideas-habria-perdido-30-alcaldias-20240304-0098.html|title=Sin Reestructuraci√≥n Municipal, Nuevas Ideas Habr√≠a Perdido 30 Alcald√≠as|trans-title=Without Municipal Reconstruction, Nuevas Ideas Would Have Lost 30 Mayorships|language=es|date=5 March 2024|access-date=5 March 2024|work=La Prensa Gr√°fica|first1=Denni|last1=Portillo}}</ref>

sentences.text: All 44 municipalities had winners declared. Nuevas Ideas, GANA, the PDC, the PCN, Solidary Force, and ARENA all won at least one mayorship, while the FMLN, Vamos, Nuestro Tiempo, Democratic Change, and the Salvadoran Patriotic Fraternity did not win any. Turnout for the municipal election was the lowest since the end of the Salvadoran Civil War in 1992. In total, the opposition won 1 mayorship, 1 trustee, 24 proprietary aldermen, and 23 substitute aldermen in 16 of the 44 municipal councils; this accounts for around 10 percent of all municipal council positions. {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} and its allies won the remaining 90 percent of municipal council positions.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/elecciones-2024-municipales-tse-/1127224/2024/|title=Candidatos a las Alcald√≠as Comienzan la Fiesta y se Declaran Ganadores de las Elecciones Municipales|trans-title=Candidates to the Mayorships Begin to Celebrate as They Are Declares Winners in the Municipal Elections|language=es|date=3 March 2024|access-date=3 March 2024|work=El Diario de Hoy|first1=E.|last1=Chac√≥n}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.laprensagrafica.com/elsalvador/Cambios-en-municipios-importantes-20240303-0118.html|title=Cambios en Municipios Importantes|trans-title=Changes in Important Municipalities|language=es|date=4 March 2024|access-date=4 March 2024|work=La Prensa Gr√°fica|first1=Gabriel|last1=Campos Madrid}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.laprensagrafica.com/elsalvador/Participacion-en-elecciones-municipales-fue-de-30.1--la-mas-baja-en-la-historia-del-TSE-20240304-0094.html|title=Participaci√≥n en Elecciones Municipales fue de 30.1%, la M√°s Baja en la Historia del TSE|trans-title=Participation in the Municipal Elections was 30.1%, the Lowest in the History of the TSE|language=es|date=5 March 2024|access-date=5 March 2024|work=La Prensa Gr√°fica|first1=Gabriela|last1=Villarroel}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diario.elmundo.sv/politica/oposicion-tendra-regidores-solo-en-la-tercera-parte-de-los-44-concejos-del-pais|title=Oposici√≥n Tendr√° Regidores Solo en la Tercera Parte de los 44 Concejos del Pa√≠s|trans-title=Opposition Will Have Aldermen in Only A Third of the 44 of the Country's Councils|language=es|date=10 April 2024|access-date=10 April 2024|work=El Mundo (El Salvador)|El Mundo|first1=Yolanda|last1=Maga√±a}}</ref>

sentences.text: Turnout for the PARLACEN election was the lowest in 25 years and reached just 29.88%. ''{{Lang|es|La Prensa Gr√°fica}}'' attributed the low turnout and almost 10 percent of the Spoilt vote|vote being blank or invalid to PARLACEN's general unpopularity in El Salvador, with many invalid ballots containing messages questioning PARLACEN's functions or relevance.

Why Was It Created, What Does It Do, and What Countries in Central America are Not In It?|language=es|work=La Prensa Gr√°fica|first1=Beatriz|last1=Calder√≥n}}</ref>

sentences.text: Shortly after polling stations closed but before the TSE officially announced the results of the presidential and legislative elections, Bukele posted on Twitter|X declaring that, "according to our numbers", he had won the presidential election with "more than 85% of the votes" and that {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}} had won "a minimum of" 58 of the Legislative Assembly's 60 seats. He also claimed that his electoral victory was "a record in the entire democratic history of the world" and that the 2024 election was "the first time in history that El Salvador has democracy, and it's not me saying it, it's the people". A crowd of Bukele's supporters gathered at the Plaza Gerardo Barrios in San Salvador to celebrate his victory. Bukele later addressed the crowd from the balcony of the National Palace (El Salvador)|National Palace and celebrated his victory in a speech, during which he criticized journalists who themselves had criticized the gang crackdown and his concentration of power. Bukele also remarked that the election results was "the first time in a country that just one party exists in a completely democratic system", adding that "the entire opposition together was pulverized".

sentences.text: Former FMLN Salvadoran President Mauricio Funes stated that the opposition was defeated "without a doubt". In a press conference on 4 February 2024, Flores stated that the FMLN would not disappear as a political entity and that it was "not correct" for Bukele to declare himself the election's winner before the TSE made an official announcement. √ìscar Ortiz thanked those who voted for Flores and stated that "history does not end here". Flores did not concede. On 5 February, Claudia Ortiz stated that "democratic spaces are closing in El Salvador, civil society is closing down and there is an environment of fear to speak out". On 7 February, S√°nchez conceded the election and congratulated Bukele on his victory.

sentences.text: After the results of the legislative election were published, Flores claimed that he had votes stolen from both him and the FMLN. Regarding Claudia Ortiz winning re-election to the Legislative Assembly with {{Lang|es|Vamos|italic=no}}, Mauricio Funes stated that she "has fought the battle and I am sure that she will continue to fight". When asked about {{Lang|es|Nuevas Ideas|italic=no}}' 500,000-vote difference between the presidential and legislative elections, Castro stated that "there is no comparison" and that such comparisons were "Apples and oranges|apples to oranges" ("{{lang|es|peras a manzanas}}") as Bukele was a "phenomenon at the global level". After GANA lost all its seats in the Legislative Assembly, Gallegos, who himself lost his seat, stated that he would continue to support Bukele regardless of his political situation.
